verses.text: While they were speaking to the people, the priests and the captain of the temple and the Sadducees came upon them.
verses.comment: The apostles face opposition from religious leaders, a recurring theme showing the continuity of Old Testament prophetic conflict. Compare with Jesus’ arrest in Luke 22:52.

verses.text: These leaders were greatly troubled because they were teaching the people and announcing in Jesus the resurrection from the dead.
verses.comment: The resurrection is central to Christian preaching. The Sadducees denied the resurrection (see Matt. 22:23), hence their alarm. Orthodox belief in bodily resurrection is fundamental, reflecting apostolic teaching.

verses.text: So they seized them and put them in custody until the next day, for it was already evening.
verses.comment: Notice the apostolic pattern of suffering and imprisonment, echoing the experience of Jesus.

verses.text: But many of those who had heard the word believed, and the number of the men came to about five thousand.
verses.comment: Growth of the early church is marked by mass conversions, signifying fulfillment of Old Testament promises of gathered people (Isaiah 2:2-3).

verses.text: On the next day their rulers and elders and scribes gathered together in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The assembly of Jerusalem’s religious authorities continues to parallel Jesus' own trial.

verses.text: With Annas the high priest and Caiaphas and John and Alexander, and all who were of the high-priestly family.
verses.comment: Annas and Caiaphas also presided at Jesus’ trial. The mention of the high-priestly family highlights the line of authority and tradition.

verses.text: When they had set them in their midst, they asked, 'By what power, or by what name, did you do this?'
verses.comment: Questioning the source of authority is significant; religious leaders seeking to defend their own authority against what they perceive as a rival claim.

verses.text: Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them, 'Rulers of the people and elders,'
verses.comment: Peter’s inspiration by the Holy Spirit fulfills Jesus’ promise that the Spirit would give words for the defense of the faith (see Matt. 10:19-20).

verses.text: 'If we are being examined today concerning a good deed done to a crippled man, by what means he was healed,'
verses.comment: Peter refers to the healing in Acts 3, emphasizing compassionate works as signs accompanying apostolic ministry.

verses.text: 'Let it be known to all of you, and to all the people of Israel, that in the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom you crucified, whom God raised from the dead, by him this man stands before you healed.'
verses.comment: Explicit Christ-centered proclamation: Jesus is crucified, resurrected, and the source of salvation and miracles. Old Testament links (Ps. 118:22) suggest messianic fulfillment.

verses.text: 'This Jesus is the stone that was rejected by you, the builders, which has become the cornerstone.'
verses.comment: Reference to Psalm 118:22, interpreted by Jesus Himself (Matt. 21:42). Christ is the cornerstone of the new covenant community; ties to apostolic succession hinted here in the foundation image.

verses.text: 'And there is salvation in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given among men by which we must be saved.'
verses.comment: Exclusive claim of salvation in Jesus—see John 14:6. This underlines orthodox Christology and the necessity of faith in the name of Christ.

verses.text: Now when they saw the boldness of Peter and John, and perceived that they were uneducated, ordinary men, they were astonished. And they recognized that they had been with Jesus.
verses.comment: Divinely inspired boldness and transformation of ordinary men through closeness with Jesus. Spiritual formation follows from real encounter.

verses.text: But seeing the man who was healed standing with them, they had nothing to say in opposition.
verses.comment: Undeniable miracle testifies to the authority of the apostles—visible proof often accompanies apostolic preaching.

verses.text: But when they had commanded them to leave the council, they conferred among themselves,
verses.comment: Standard courtroom practice; religious leaders struggle to maintain control.

verses.text: 'What shall we do with these men? For, indeed, a notable sign has been performed through them, and it is evident to all the residents of Jerusalem, and we cannot deny it.'
verses.comment: The public nature of apostolic miracles makes denial impossible; reminiscent of reactions to Jesus’ miracles (John 11:47).

verses.text: 'But in order that it may not spread further among the people, let us warn them to speak no more to anyone in this name.'
verses.comment: The authorities seek to suppress the proclamation of Jesus’ name, fearing its influence.

verses.text: So they called them and charged them not to speak or teach at all in the name of Jesus.
verses.comment: Official decree tries to silence the faith; this sets up later conflict as the apostles persist (see Acts 5:28).

verses.text: But Peter and John answered them, 'Whether it is right in the sight of God to listen to you rather than to God, you must judge,'
verses.comment: The primacy of obedience to God over human authority. Later developed doctrine emphasizes this principle for church leaders (see Acts 5:29).

verses.text: 'For we cannot but speak of what we have seen and heard.'
verses.comment: Apostolic witness is based on direct experience of Christ, stressing an embodied and handed-down tradition (see 1 John 1:1-3).

verses.text: And when they had further threatened them, they let them go, finding no way to punish them, because of the people; for all were praising God for what had happened.
verses.comment: The popular support protects the apostles; visible works bring glory to God and attract public affirmation.

verses.text: For the man on whom this miracle of healing was performed was more than forty years old.
verses.comment: Additional detail underlines the enduring nature of the affliction and the power of the healing.

verses.text: When they were released, they went to their own companions and reported everything that the chief priests and elders had said to them.
verses.comment: The apostolic fellowship remains united, sharing both burdens and triumphs—a spiritual family guided by ordained leadership.

verses.text: When they heard it, they lifted their voices together to God and said, 'Sovereign Lord, who made the heaven and the earth and the sea and everything in them,'
verses.comment: Corporate prayer affirms God as Creator and Sovereign. Unified worship and prayer is foundational, reflecting the gathered body’s communion.

verses.text: 'who, through the Holy Spirit, spoke by our father David, your servant, saying, ‘Why did the Gentiles rage, and the peoples plot in vain?’'
verses.comment: Psalm 2 is quoted, interpreted as prophecy of Christ. David, called 'your servant' and inspired by the Holy Spirit, sets a precedent for understanding Scripture as divinely inspired and interpreted within the community.

verses.text: 'The kings of the earth took their stand, and the rulers gathered together against the Lord and against his anointed.'
verses.comment: Direct continuation of the Psalm 2 prophecy—interpreted as fulfilled in the opposition to Jesus.

verses.text: 'For truly in this city they were gathered together against your holy servant Jesus, whom you anointed, both Herod and Pontius Pilate, together with the Gentiles and the peoples of Israel,'
verses.comment: The fulfillment of prophecy in Jesus’ suffering ties together the Old and New Testament narratives. The anointed 'servant' is a loaded term, recalling Isaiah’s Servant Songs and linking to messianic understanding.

verses.text: 'to do whatever your hand and your plan had predestined to take place.'
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty governs salvation history. The idea of divine predestination emphasizes providence and the assurance of God’s plan unfolding through appointed leaders.

verses.text: 'And now, Lord, take note of their threats, and grant to your servants to speak your word with all boldness,'
verses.comment: Prayer for courage; the spirit-empowered proclamation of the Word is central to mission and ministry.

verses.text: 'while you stretch out your hand to heal, and signs and wonders are performed through the name of your holy servant Jesus.'
verses.comment: Prayer for ongoing miracles through Jesus' name; sign gifts confirm apostolic witness. Note that the request is for continued visible evidence, showing that miraculous signs accompany true doctrine.

verses.text: And when they had prayed, the place where they were gathered was shaken, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and spoke the word of God with boldness.
verses.comment: Physical manifestations of the Spirit’s presence recur throughout apostolic gatherings. The group is filled anew, showing continual empowerment.

verses.text: Now the full number of those who believed were of one heart and soul, and no one claimed that any of the things that belonged to him was his own, but they had everything in common.
verses.comment: Apostolic community exhibits profound spiritual and material unity. This radical sharing is seen as the fruit of sanctifying grace and the communal nature of the church.

verses.text: And with great power the apostles were giving their testimony to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and great grace was upon them all.
verses.comment: Apostolic testimony is central and accompanied by a unique grace granted to the whole community—reflecting the outpouring of spiritual gifts and the effectiveness of apostolic authority.

verses.text: There was not a needy person among them, for as many as were owners of lands or houses sold them and brought the proceeds of what was sold
verses.comment: The church lives out the Old Testament ideal of caring for the poor (see Deut. 15:4), demonstrating tangible charity as a sign of authentic faith community.

verses.text: and laid it at the feet of the apostles, and it was distributed to each as any had need.
verses.comment: Giving at the apostles' feet signifies submission to apostolic authority. Distribution as needed points to organized governance and stewardship in the church.

verses.text: Thus Joseph, who was called by the apostles Barnabas (which means Son of Encouragement), a Levite, a native of Cyprus,
verses.comment: Barnabas’ nickname from the apostles indicates a tradition of bestowed names, hinting at a deeper community of faith with authority to recognize and confer spiritual roles.

verses.text: sold a field that belonged to him and brought the money and laid it at the apostles' feet.
verses.comment: Barnabas models sacrificial giving and complete trust in apostolic authority—a pattern for stewardship within the church. This emphasizes the importance of unity, obedience, and generosity in the faith community.
